msDesc.head: Compilation of legal and language texts

summary.seg: The contents of this manuscript comprise a mixture of legal and language texts: notes relating not only to laws and court procedures but also in aid of correct French grammar and conversation. Though there are frequent changes in scribal hand, often though not always coinciding with divisions between the quires, the manuscript is likely not a composite but one formed of codicological units copied more or less around the same time. The reason is that this particular combination of subjects bears similarities to the courses on dictamen, conveyancing, court-keeping and French language taught at Oxford during the fifteenth century. That this volume contains fictional cases in which one of the parties concerned is 'W.K.', and the existence of similar combinations of notes in other manuscripts, has led scholars to propose that the notes in this volume derive from the teaching of William Kingsmill William Kingsmill. Kingsmill had been a scrivener of London from at least 1402 until at least 1419, and was also under-marshal of the King's Bench until his dismissal around the same time (for a brief biography of Kingsmill, see Jonathon Bush, Learning the law: teaching and the transmission of English law, 1150-1900 (London: Hambledon, 1999), pp. 167-70). He taught thereafter in Oxford, and perhaps as late as 1450.

Kingsmill's treatise De forma et compositione cartarum, a guide to the correct composition of legal documents, is preserved in another University Library manuscript, MS Dd.5.46. This other manuscript is datable to c. 1429 on the basis of most of its deeds being dated with the regnal year 7 Henry VI (1428-29), with a copy of an Inquisition dated 1430 being added on the flyleaves, and is thus the earliest datable version of his conveyancing course known to survive in manuscript. Given the compilatory nature of the present manuscript, which suggests copying from other manuscripts and lecture notes in circulation in Oxford, it is likely that it dates from around the same period.

Dr James Freeman
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: French language and vocabulary, beginning with pronunciation and conjugations
msItem.explicit: 7r: quatrecentisme quarantisme et septisme et cetera
msItem.note: This and the following item are probably notes from a course of instruction.

There are other versions in Cambridge, University Library, MS Ee.4.20 (ff. 165r-166r) and MS Gg.6.44 (ff. 19r-30r). Cf. Cambridge, Trinity College, MS B.14.40, f. 149r (printed by Meyer, Romania (1903), 32: p. 49; Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Rawlinson C.507, p. 106.

msItem.title: Guide to French conversation
msItem.incipit: 7v: Sir bon jour sir bon jour a vous
msItem.explicit: 13r: douszeme esquilez in douszeme sancere et cetera
msItem.note: One of a group of French conversation manuals, known as La manière de langage .
Legge (1939) attributes the work to William Kingsmill William Kingsmill.

msItem.title: Notes on tenures
msItem.incipit: 13v: Feodum et jus in feodo simplici

msItem.title: Notes on common appendant (c. 1490), citing year-book cases from Edw. II to Mich. 5 Hen. VII
Three forms of presentment for felony, relating to Oxford, 21 Hen. VI
Notes on common, citing cases from Edw. III to Mich. 5 Hen. VII
msItem.incipit: 14v: Et nota que sount quater maners de comon
msItem.note: Cf. related mnemonic note in Cambridge, University Library, MS Mm.5.2, f. 78*r and MS Add. 7558, f. 57r, and Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Rawlinson C.507, p. 190

msItem.title: Old Tenures
msItem.incipit: 15r: Tenura dicitur per servicium militare per servicium socagii...En primes est assavoire que tener per service de chivaler est tener per homage, feaulte, escuage
msItem.explicit: 24v: deins lan per un scire facias
msItem.finalRubric: 24v: Liber est scriptus qui scripsit sit benedictus
msItem.textLang: Middle French, with beginning of text in Latin
msItem.note: This is the latest of several elementary treatises on tenures, and belongs to the later 14th century; there is an internal reference to 21 Edw. III on f. 18r. It was first printed c. 1494 by Ricard Pynson (S.T.C. 23877.7. ff. 15r-20v correspond with Cambridge, University Library, MS Gg.6.44, ff. 1r-12v.

There are other versions (most of them beginning, as in the printed version, 'Tenir per service de chivaler est...'):
CUL, MS Gg.6.7, ff. 1r-12v
CUL, MS Ll.4.17, ff. 233r-234v
CUL, MS Mm.3.30, ff. 2r-7v
Cambridge, Pembroke College, MS 271, f. 80v
Cambridge, St John's College, MS C.13, f. 1r
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.3.56, f. 1r
Cambridge (MA), Harvard Law School Library, MS 31, f. 1r
Cambridge (MA), Harvard Law School Library, MS 44, f. 29v ('En primez est assavoir', abridged)
Exeter, Cathedral Library, MS 3533, f. 43r
Holkham Hall, MS 755 (HMC, 9th Report, App., 374)
London, British Library, Harley MS 408, f. 3v
London, British Library, Harley MS 548, f. 9r
London, British Library, Harley MS 926, f. 3r
London, British Library, Harley MS 1807, f. 2r
London, British Library, Harley MS 4844(1), f. 51v
London, British Library, Harley MS 5146, f. 3r
London, British Library, Lansdowne MS 559, f. 62v
London, British Library, Add MS 17514, f. 2r ('Expliciunt tenure scripte in anno Domini mo cccco xlii'
London, British Library, Add MS 22552, f. 19r ('De primes est assavoir que tenir per service de chivaler')
London, British Library, Add MS 38008, f. 90r ('Tenir per service de chivaler')
London, British Library, Add MS 38131, f. 73v (fragment)
London, Lincoln's Inn, MS Hale 184, f. 18r (fragment)
Manchester, John Rylands Library, MS Lat. 252, f. 92r ('Cy comensent les services. Tenire par service de chivaler'
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Lat. misc. c. 66, f. 101b verso (beginning only)
San Marino (CA), Huntington Library, MS HM 47619, f. 7r (Dutschke 2:730; fragment)

msItem.title: An elementary course on procedure and pleading
msItem.incipit: 25r: Curia baronis et etiam regalis. En primez coment quen lune court et lautre soient appellez essoynez et profrez
msItem.explicit: 48v: responsio potest dari preter debet vel non debet detinet vel non detinet
msItem.finalRubric: 48v: Explicit liber da mihi quod ego merui quod Mershfeld
msItem.note: This is an elementary course on procedure and pleading, perhaps delivered at Oxford, which is mentioned in the precedents. (Mershfeld may have been an Oxford student: see Provenance).

There are a number of different texts called Curia baronis, and their interrelationship is complex. They contain a mixture of guidance in French, with specimens of oral pleading, entries in Latin, and charges and oaths in English. The present text corresponds with CUL MS Gg.6.44, ff. 30v-65r. It is probably from William Kingsmill William Kingsmill's course at Oxford, for which see Baker and Ringrose (1996), pp. 33-34. The same incipit also occurs in:
Dublin, Trinity College, MS 662, f. 24r
Holkham Hall, MS 754 (HMC, 9th Report, App., 315)
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Lat. misc. e. 103, f. 1r (where many precedents have the initials W.K., presumably for Kingsmill)
Oxford, Merton College, MS 297B, f. 9r
Legge (1939) attributes to Kingsmill the part of the text commencing on f. 33r, where 'W.K.' is brought in as one of the parties to the actions.

It is a late version, quite similar to that first printed c. 1525 as Modus observandi curiam cum leta (S.T.C. 7713.7). It is different from the collection first printed c. 1501 as Modus tenendi curiam baronis (S.T.C. 7705.7), for which see CUL, MS Ee.1.3, ff. 13r-20r. Cf. also CUL, MS Add. 7558, ff. 29v-30r, 41r-56v. On f. 32v there are some mnemonic verses on wager of law ('Qui legem vadiat nisi lex in tempore fiat | Tunc condempnetur taxatio sic sibi detur'): see CUL, MS Gg.5.30, f. 165r (Baker and Ringrose (1996), p. 305).

msItem.title: Astrological notes, notes on the humours
Treatise on law and procedure in London
msItem.textLang: Middle French, with opening rubric in Latin
msItem.rubric: 53v: Intratur in libro de custumis in Camera Guyhalde Ciuitatis London Foliis quinto vito, viimo, viiio, ixo, pertini in prima parte
msItem.incipit: 53v: En primes les maire et audermans de la cite de Loundres teignent
msItem.explicit: 65v: partie auera respouncement contre esteant cell enquest doffice
msItem.finalRubric: 65v: Et fair assavoir qu sount plusurs autres pointz et usages touchamitz les Courtz des viscomtz doun homme ne poet mye avoir remembraunce de toutz
msItem.note: Cf. the tract on Lincoln procedure in CUL, MS Add. 7558, ff. 30r-37r.

msItem.title: Account of miracles that prompted the Magi to travel to the Nativity
msItem.incipit: 65v: Ista erant miracula que movebant magos querere salvatorem. Balthsara habuit ortum aromaticum
msItem.explicit: 65v: In cuius signum triginta tribus diebus vivam et tunc moriar quod ita factum est

msItem.title: Statute of Apprentices
msItem.incipit: 66r: Item ordeignez est et establiez que les bones estatutz faitz
msItem.explicit: 67r: levez et paiez en aide de la quinszisme agramitier en temps avenir et cetere
msItem.textLang: Middle French, with explicit in Latin

msItem.title: Play on the word 'count'
msItem.incipit: 67r: Je vey un count comptant un cont a le viscount

msItem.title: Specimens of French speech and vocabulary
msItem.rubric: 67v: Ici a nostre comencement de cesti tretis nous dirrons ainsi
msItem.incipit: 67v: En noun de pier et filz et seint esprit amen. En noun de la glorius Trinite
msItem.explicit: 87r: et piteons ottroit eu le fine sil liu pleast amen
msItem.finalRubric: 87r: Ici fine le commune parlance nulle meliour en tout le France
msItem.textLang: Middle French, with a few interlinear glosses in Middle English
msItem.note: Includes various forms of La manière de langage : see Meyer (1886), p. 262.
For other versions, see CUL, MS Add. 8870, ff. 34r-35r.

msItem.title: Form of a bond by Guy Wikam of Whicheford, conditioned to perform an arbitration award, before the feasts of SS. Simon and Jude, 2 Hen. VII.

note.p: Numbering in ink, mostly in the centre of the upper margin of the rectos. Owing to dirt or damage, no numbers are visible on the first (1) or last (88) leaves. Three leaves were omitted from this sequence of foliation, after 15, 35 and 37; these have been numbered in pencil, in two different ways, apparently during the 20th century. References to folio numbers and letters are preferred over asterisks, and are followed in this description.

collation.p:
The manuscript comprises seven quires of varying numbers of leaves, perhaps formed from four codicological units: ff. 1-14, 15-24, 25-48 and 49-88.
Quire 114 (ff. 1-14)
Quire 212-1 (ff. 15-24: 12th leaf excised, after f. 24, probably blank)
Quire 312 (ff. 25-35)
Quire 414 (ff. 36-48)
Quire 58 (ff. 49-56)
Quire 618-1 (ff. 57-73: 1st leaf, before f. 57, cancelled)
Quire 716-1 (ff. 74-88: 12th leaf, after f. 84, missing. The stub of the missing leaf has been misbound, appearing between ff. 78 and 79, rather than ff. 84 and 85)
114; 212-1 (12th excised, probably blank); 312, 414; 58, 618-1 (1st cancelled), 716-1 (12th missing)

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Mainly single columns (except ff. 1v-5r and 49r-51v, which have two columns, and 5v, which has three). 25-31 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: Folios 1r-13r, 15r-21r and 25r-37r written in secretary hands.
Folios 13v-14v, 21v-24v, 37v-48v, 49v-51v, 52r-67r, 67v-87r and 87v-88v display predominantly anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Plain red initials (ff. 6r, 7v, 15r, 25r, 26v, 53v, 65v, 67v), in one instance ornamented with red-brown infill and marginal flourishing (f. 26v).
Cadel in black ink, with red infill (f. 67v), and practices / pen-trials for interlaced cadel decoration (f. 24v).

Outline genealogical diagram illustrating the descent and relationship between members of two branches of a family connected by two brothers/brothers-in-law, involving individuals named in the case described above (Adam, Symon, Geffray, Wylliam, Robert Thomas and John) (f. 46v).

note.p: Calculations written by a post-medieval hand on blank spaces (ff. 49r, 51r).
Additions to the margins by another post-medieval hand on ff. 2r and 4r.
Collation formula by the hand of H.L. Pink Pink, H. L., c. 1958 ([ii] recto).

binding.p: From note by binder pasted on rear pastedown: 'Spine covered with brown Oasis Morocco, marbled paper sides, vellum tips, lettering labels.' Note of work signed "SMC" ('Sydney Morris Cockerell', i.e. Sandy Cockerell Cockerell, Sydney Morris, October 1958.
Binding removed in 1958 described by Sandy Cockerell as follows: 'Narrow brown sheep skin spine, faded green paper sides over millboards. Book sewn on three thin cords.'

note.p: 'It is credibly supposed that much of this volume derives from one of the courses on dictamen, conveyancing, court-keeping and French language at Oxford, probably that given by William Kingsmill William Kingsmill.'

provenance.p: 48v: Colophon contains the name 'Mershfeld', perhaps a student attending the course at Oxford.
50v: 'Jhon Balding', perhaps a former owner of the manuscript.

history.acquisition: The precise date of acquisition by Cambridge University Library is not known. The manuscript is first recorded in a catalogue compiled in 1753 (now MS Oo.7.53), with 'R' next to the classmark, denoting it as one of the books that came to the Library in 1715 from the collection of John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 , via the gift of George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 , following the Moore's death the previous year. However, the manuscript cannot be identified among those listed as being in Moore's collection, either in Bernard, Catalogi librorum (1697) or in the handwritten supplement compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) Tanner, Thomas, 1674-1735 (CUL, MS Oo.7.50(2)), nor is there any evidence of the manuscript having contained a Royal Library bookplate.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the description provided by John Baker and Jayne Ringrose, Catalogue of English Legal Manuscripts in Cambridge University Library (1996) (used here by kind permission of the Boydell Press).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

custodialHist.custEvent: The manuscript was sent for conservation and rebinding c. 1958, at which time the condition of the item was described as follows by Sandy Cockerell Cockerell, Sydney Morris: 'Sewing and cords broken. Vellum in fair condition though leaves stained, dirty damaged and dogeared with parts missing at beginning and end. First leaf very dirty and worn, obliterating the text. Some water staining and running of colours, particularly on leaves 50 and 51' (see Binding for further details). Water staining is to be found on ff. 42-56. There are also ink splashes on ff. 9v-10r. Losses to the upper margin and upper outer corner of the leaves on ff. 73-88, perhaps caused by rodents.
